parseDate
Converts a string date value into "Date" or "Date and Time" format.
This function can be used in
data integration
scenarios when a date from an external service comes in form of a string.
Syntax
parseDate
(date, format)
Setting
Purpose
date
The date string.
This parameter can be passed as text
attribute
, text
variable
or
text
.
format
The format to which the date string is converted.
Acceptable formats:
date - "dd.MM.yyyy";
date and time - "dd.MM.yyyy HH:mm".
Key Representations.
Literal
Literal meaning
y
Year
M
Month in year
d
Day in month
H
Hour in day (0-23)
m
Minute in hour (0-59)
s
Second in minute (0-59)
It is important to consider the case sensitivity of the literal.
This parameter can be passed as text
attribute
, text
variable
or
text
.
Note
Adding the function is done through manual input following these rules:
The sequence of time units in the parameters must match.
Correct format:
parseDate("24/07/2023", "dd/MM/yyyy")
Incorrect format:
parseDate("24/07/2023", "yyyy/MM/dd")
The separators used in the string must match those in the conversion format.
Correct format:
parseDate("24.07.2023 19:42", "dd.MM.yyyy HH:mm")
parseDate("24/07/2023", "dd/MM/yyyy")
Incorrect format:
parseDate("24.07.2023 19:42", "dd.MM.yyyy HH.mm")
parseDate("24/07/2023", "dd.MM.yyyy")
Example
A string date value can be converted to a "Date" type for further manipulation within the specified algorithm.
For example, to return the date value of the third working day after the date "02.03.2023," declared as a string, the following algorithm can be written:
The parseDate function is used to convert the string value "02.03.2023" to the "Date" type in the specified format.
Other functions used in writing this algorithm.
See more.
The variable "date" is declared using the
var
function.
The
getWorkDay
function is used to calculate the date of the working day following "02.03.2023" after 3 days.
The calendar selection is done using the
dict
function.
